title: Aspirations, Expectations and Education Outcomes for Children in Britain: Considering Relative Measures of Family Efficiency.
abstractText:
Distance (benefit) function methodology will be used to analyse household production of child education outcomes.

This approach considers the family to be analogous to a small factory trying to maximise its output given an amount of resources it can use as inputs.  In particular, the family's ability to efficiently and simultaneously generate dual education outputs for their children subject to multiple (but constrained) input availabilities. 

The distance that the observed family's combined output sits from the estimated production frontier can be interpreted as a measure of their technical inefficiency or, alternatively, an indication of how much more output they could have had if they had used their input mixture differently.

This provides a comparable measure, with a natural interpretation, that can be used to make relative statements concerning successful child education outcomes across families. Furthermore, factors that may be associated with differences in families' productive efficiencies can be explored within this framework. Amongst these possible factors, the relationship between parental aspirations and the child's expectations and the relative efficiency of the family when producing these dual education outputs will be explored.
